title: Baby Copperhead Snake Identification: 6 Things to Look For

steps.title: Light green or yellow tail
steps.content: Light green or yellow tail This is the one physical trait that sets baby copperheads apart from adult copperheads. Until around 3 or 4 years of age, the tip of the baby copperhead’s tail will be a light shade of yellow or green, which they use to lure prey. [1] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source

steps.title: 7 to 9 inches (18 to 23 cm) long
steps.content: 7 to 9 inches (18 to 23 cm) long Fully grown adults will be around 60 to 90 cm (24 to 36 in) in length. [2] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source

steps.title: Triangular, spear-shaped head
steps.content: Triangular, spear-shaped head The spear-shaped head is a distinct feature of venomous snakes due to the placement of the large venom glands in their mouths. The head itself is wider than the neck and is the same coppery color as the rest of its body. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Hourglass-shaped pattern
steps.content: Hourglass-shaped pattern The brown or reddish-brown bands running down the copperhead’s back is one of its most distinct features that sets it apart from other snake species. The bands are wider on the top and bottom and narrower in the middle, making them look like hourglasses. [4] X Research source The scales of the copperhead are keeled, meaning that each scale has a raised ridge. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Narrow, vertical pupils
steps.content: Narrow, vertical pupils The pupil of the copperhead is similar to a cat’s in that it is vertical and elliptical-shaped. The copperhead’s irises are a pale gold color while the pupils are dark. [6] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source

steps.title: Heat-sensory pits
steps.content: Heat-sensory pits These are located on each side of the copperhead’s head between the eyes and nostrils. This is another common trait of pit vipers, and they use these pits to sense the heat of their prey so that they can accurately strike. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Corn snakes have brighter red scales than copperheads.
steps.content: Corn snakes have brighter red scales than copperheads. Also, the thickest part of the hourglass pattern on the corn snake will be on its back, whereas it is more commonly found on the sides of the copperhead. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Northern water snakes don’t have the copperhead’s spear-shaped head.
steps.content: Northern water snakes don’t have the copperhead’s spear-shaped head. Its pupils are also round, not slits. Both of these are traits of non-venomous snakes. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Eastern Hognose snakes have an upturned snout that resembles that of a pig.
steps.content: Eastern Hognose snakes have an upturned snout that resembles that of a pig. The colors, scale patterns, and even habitats of the eastern hognose snake closely resemble those of the copperhead, and thus often cause confusion between the two. The eastern hognose even puffs out its neck to make its head appear triangular so that it can scare off predators. [10] X Research source

steps.title: The copperhead can be found throughout the eastern region of the United States.
steps.content: The copperhead can be found throughout the eastern region of the United States. The range of their territory is expansive, going from the Florida panhandle northwards to Massachusetts and westwards all the way to Nebraska. [11] X Research source They also occupy territories in southern New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Copperheads prefer the wetlands.
steps.content: Copperheads prefer the wetlands. While the copperhead can live in various habitats, they can often be found near rivers, swamps, and reservoirs. [13] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source During the winter, their dens can be found on the fringes of rivers, swamps, and other marsh areas. During the peak of summer, they will be in these wetland swamps and marshes, but will also inhabit open meadows and fields during the warm season. [14] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source They will rarely be found in dry areas. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Copperheads like places where they can hide.
steps.content: Copperheads like places where they can hide. Therefore, you can also find them occupying rocky, forested hillsides, piles of rotting wood or sawdust, and even construction sites. [16] X Research source Though they usually stay on the ground, copperheads can also climb low trees and bushes when hunting. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Copperheads are active during both the day and the night.
steps.content: Copperheads are active during both the day and the night. During the spring and fall, when temperatures aren’t at their extremes, copperheads will be out hunting during the day. However, they become nocturnal in the summer to avoid the heat during peak daylight hours. [18] X Research source Copperheads especially like to be out on a warm, humid night after it has just rained. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Baby copperheads are typically born in the late summer and fall.
steps.content: Baby copperheads are typically born in the late summer and fall. Mating season for copperheads occurs in the spring, though a fall mating can also occur. Female copperheads normally give birth to 3 to 10 babies in August and September. [20] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source Baby copperheads are equipped with their fangs and a venom that is just as potent as an adult’s right from birth. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Migration for copperheads occurs in the spring and fall.
steps.content: Migration for copperheads occurs in the spring and fall. It has been hypothesized by scientists that copperheads migrate to their summer feeding areas during the late spring and return home in early fall. [22] X Research source
